Assuming you know what Cookie Clicker is, I cannot recommend this version of the game for one reason, that being the game takes an immense amount of time for anything to occur. Playing the game is a chore, especially early on, and honestly I'm not sure if you are intended to play through it all or just keep it open in the background. There are upgrades allowing you to generate cookies while offline, but they come later in the game and are honestly insulting as they give but a fraction of your total cookie production. I just can't comprehend what the average player is meant to do here. Other idle games have no problem calculating offline progress. I want to give the game a positive review for its other elements that I think are enjoyable but the fact that I have to keep the game on overnight to make any sort of decent progress is a big turn-off for me.

It wasnt cus it was a good thing, but becaues i was determined to get all the rebirth stuff. however even after that, the game isnt that fun or great. You let it run in the bg and make cookies which doesnt do much else than make you gain more faster.

The game lacks a serious amount of special effects or content. It is just farming cookies over and over with no side context. The "minigames" u get from spending sugar isnt even that great or helpful nor fun.

Overall its not great for being a game that costs now. Literally better to just get it for free.

This game makes for a pretty good clicker but a terrible idler. I suppose it's called Cookie Clicker and not Idle Cookies for a reason. 

The reason why is that progression in this game is extremely slow, especially at the start, unless you're constantly paying attention to it and clicking the golden cookies that appear every two minute or so on the screen. 

Unlike in many other similar games where you can sorta choose between the active and the passive route, in this one the only way to get any semblance of progress at all is through big combos, which, while they are quite satisfying when you pull them off, are almost entirely reliant on RNG, which can make for a very frustrating experience if you're not the gambling type.

So this game takes up a lot of your time and attention, but it's not like it offers anything riveting in return, and most of the time you'll just find yourself blankly staring at the screen waiting for something to happen, occasionally spamming your left click, and the rest of the time it'll be in the back of your mind, distracting you from your other activities, but not in a good way.

The fact that there isn't even any offline progress until you unlock it through the ascension mechanic, and even then it's only a pitiful fraction of what you'd make with the game open, that was the nail in the coffin. To me the whole point of this kind of game is that comforting feeling of having something running in the background, progressing without needing input, and never feeling obligated to check back on it but being happy to do so because I'll know I'll be rewarded for my patience. I didn't find that with this game. It was fun for a few hours, maybe from the nostalgia factor as I remember playing this on browser many years ago, but it got old pretty quick.

As for the fact this game isn't free-to-play unlike most clicker/idlers, that's actually one of the few positives for me, as in this case it means no tantalizing micro-transactions. Its price is very cheap anyways... However if you value your time, I'd stay away from this one as it'll eat up a lot more of it than it ought to.

There are two main categories for why this isn't recommended. The first is the technical issues, the second is the gameplay issues, so let's get into these.

First off, I did NOT have issues with save files being deleted, instead I've had a number of other problems that aren't really unexpected. Cookie clicker was written in javascript, which doesn't really handle user interfaces at high framerates very well in general and never really has. This leads to lag in everything from cookie clicker to the secret world, so I had hoped that the steam port would have changed from javascript to C++ or python or something, but alas it has not. This means random interface lag spikes on a fairly frequent basis, to the point they actually interfere with gameplay.

For example, not only can you visibly see lag spikes when trying to click the cookie quickly, where it'll pause for half a second at a time ignoring all input in that time, where a stream of numbers has a clear gap, the freezing has made certain things like the chain-cookie be broken due to freezing and ignoring inputs on a 1-2 second window of opportunity for rare events. This is frustrating, but not game breaking.

What is game breaking, however, is after I reached about the octillion range of cookies, the game stopped responding properly when tabbed out of it. If anything other than cookie clicker is the focus window, even with just like a text document partially obscuring the window but being the focus, cookie clicker slows down, then freezes entirely and it stops updating at all. it will sit there forever, without change, until you tab back into it. Several tests have confirmed that a golden cookie effect, such as the X7 frenzy, will sit there never going down, and you can time it for a minute, then tab back in, it'll jump ahead about 10 seconds quickly, then continue like nothing happened.

...Yeah, an idle game which can't idle. You literally need to sit on the game at all times after a point to continue playing, rather than having it running in the background while you do other stuff. This completely defeats the entire purpose of an idle game, and for that reason alone, it would already be a negative review, but it doesn't end there.

Now we get into the gameplay issues.

Even if you have no technical issues with the game, the gameplay... well, cookie clicker was, to my knowledge, the very first idle game. It hasn't exactly aged well. Compared to other idle games, it requires an enormous amount of attention paid to the game, and progresses incredibly slowly.

Even when you're just first starting the game, it takes a very long time to get it up and running properly, and you start hitting long progress walls very quickly.

I first started cookie clicker this time because I was hit with the nasty flu going around this year, and couldn't concentrate on much anything other than an idle game for a few days. This meant spending basically 100% of my waking hours focused on cookie clicker actively, getting all the golden cookies and so on. It still took about 2.5 days for the first acension reset at 113 chips. For most other more modern games in the genre, this usually takes about 1-3 hours for the same effect.

The progression is... slow. Even with building up a large cookie store and doing the x7 +lucky cookie bonus (combo occurs roughly every 3.5 minutes if you're actively playing for about 220 minutes worth of production bonus), it still will produce almost nothing of real progression.

The one exception to this, is an odd spike where if you unlock the magic "minigame" and keep it stocked up in reserve, and wait for a x7 bonus, then also a x41 or so building multiplier, then trigger the magic effect to generate a new golden cookie with about a 25% chance to trigger a click frenzy X777 clicking bonus, you can increase your cookie total by a factor of about 1,000x where you would otherwise be reasonably able to attain. This doesn't really allow you to progress from that point, but it does let you unlock a lot of achievements and have more golden chips to spend when you do the ascension reset. Using this, in 4 resets I was able to get into the decillion range of cookies and ran into a new set of problems which is very bad... running out of stuff to do.

I'm only a few days into the game and already the cursor building has run out of all upgrades. The last upgrade for it showed up at 450 cursors and I'm already up to 550 now. Grandmas are about to run dry, and looking at the upgrades which are available, it's clear that this is going to cause a real problem soon, because the scaling of the game is about for every 1,000x more cookies you get, your production goes up by about x60. This is falling off quickly as there are fewer upgrades to purchase, fewer achievements, and they don't scale infinitely, but rather every upgrade and achievement are individually crafted with amusing text descriptions, which is nice, keeps the game funny and enjoyable while they last, but unlike an infinite scaling setup it means they start running out fast too.

In short, the gameplay of the game is running out only a few days into the game. Yes, there are new things gradually opened up to unlock, but it's at the expense of previous, standardized things becoming defunct. Also, the newer gameplay elements take days at a time to be beneficial, built for extremely long play. The problem with this, as covered, is that the game is bizarrely active, and you're expected to click a golden cookie roughly every 90-110 seconds or suffer a huge loss in production and the game is balanced around the assumption you are doing this continually for days on end. You can't tab out properly as discussed earlier, and you can't really 'do' anything of value except wait for the next golden cookie to spawn every 1.5 to 2 minutes.

So... yeah. As an idle game, it's kind of really just not that good. It has a place in terms of history as being the first idle game, and if you're sick for a week it's an alright way to burn some time, but... as an idle game goes, it's too active to be idle, and the idle upgrades to make it possible to turn it off come in too late and are vastly inferior to playing actively to the point it's not really worth bothering with.

If you want an active idle game, go play Idle Wizard instead. I can't really recommend cookie clicker compared to the other free options out there when it just does the same thing as others but worse. It clearly has not kept up with newer innovations in the idle clicker genre.

If nothing else, the fact that it's still running on javascript alone should be good enough of a warning to stay away from it.

Cookie Clicker was the first of its kind and the genre-definer, but the game doesn't hold up on its own. 

I know that it's a clicker, and I played it years ago before it came to Steam, but I just can't feel entertained enough to keep clicking or playing. Seeing numbers go up makes you feel excited, but as soon as you stall it feels really disheartening to be forced to leave your computer running all throughout the night just to make progress in the game.

There's many basic features that should be available from the very moment you start playing, but they are locked behind upgrades that you'll only be able to unlock after ascending. Some even after ascending multiple times, which takes way too much grind to achieve.

The market minigame feels kind of pointless, and getting more wizard towers to get more mana is also pointless because mana costs scale with the towers you own. You're expected to sell them in order to get another shot at it, but not telling the player how to do it at all feels like a problem, not to mention getting the quantity right. It's counter-intuitive to sell anything at all because you crimp your cookie production, even when you have buffs like the idol that boosts your production after selling buildings.

The music is nice, but design-wise the game is pretty bad. I wouldn't recommend buying it if it's not on sale. Alternatively you could just play the web version which is free.
As fun as this game is, it's an utter waste of time. Go play some other, actually good game or spend your time doing something productive :P

Compared to Adventure Capitalist this game is shorter and more dependent on both luck and active-play.

+ No micro-transactions
+ Decent progression through achievements and restarts
+ Numbers go up
+ Enjoyed running through the main game, maxing building and heavenly upgrades

- Luck plays a significant factor 
- Confusing. To really progress through the main game requires a decent amount of active play trying to get golden cookie combos, but once you've unlocked all of that you're suddenly gated by weeks to months of waiting for "sugar lumps" to grow.
- Personally I did not enjoy the "minigames" like garden or stock exchange. They're a frustrating combination of relying on luck whilst being forced to wait yet forced to pay attention.

TLDR: The main game is reasonable fun for a few £. Uninstall after getting all the building unlocks. Don't bother with "sugar lumps" or minigames.

Ideally I'd give this a neutral rating, but that's not an option.

The game itself works just fine, and it's a fine time waster, until you realize you've been staring at this idle game for hours waiting for golden cookies while on your phone, and it's the fifth day you've been doing this. You're not even playing anything anymore, you're just waiting to click one object on a screen. I removed this curse from my account and I advise you to not fall into the trap.

Look, I have fond memories of the browser version as much as the next person, and I think Orteil getting some money for his work producing... effectively the entire idle game genre (if it wasn't the original idle game, Cookie Clicker definitely was the populariser) is good, actually (especially as paying less than a price of cookie for a downloadable version is about the least evil way of going about earning said money) but... Cookie Clicker is just kind of soul destroying to actually play (and I swear the progression curve is way less generous now which intensifies the issue by requiring longer play times to reach, e.g., the endgame grandmapocalypse, but I am not reinstalling to check the patch notes for balance changes or whatever because... no no that does not seem like a good idea for me). 

And that is kind of a big problem because we only have so much time on this Earth and I don't think clicking a picture of a cookie while continually monitoring a fictional stock market is a good way to spend it? 

Okay, you could say this point about pointlessness about pretty much any game, but Cookie Clicker is a game that wears the contradictions of video gaming on its sleeve (and so renders them particularly sharp) and while that does make it genuinely interesting from an artistic and satirical standpoint, it does still not make the actual experience of playing it good or healthy - indeed the feeling of compulsion I have to do something so openly and honestly pointless is probably actively unhealthy! (there's a reason I uninstalled after a few days!) - and I kind of have to base a recommendation of whether you should actually play this game on that.

tl;dr As much as a game about massively overproducing cookies being bad for you is kind of fitting... it is still kind of bad for you so maybe don't play it? Like eating a ton of actual cookies might straight up be better for you (or at the very least less bad), in addition to being more enjoyable







.... ... ... ... ... Okay, also, as a petty point, I swear the performance I've experienced is less than ideal. My machine does default to using the integrated GPU rather than the dedicated... but this does not feel like a game that should end up using basically all of said integrated GPU and making my computer straight up sound like a plane taking off at times, even with all the fancy bits turned off? Of course, this may be semi-inherent in Electron, based off my vague memories of using the Atom text editor back when that first came out, but I'm not sure and it is kind of a problem: as much as Cookie Clicker feels like it ought to be able to run on very low end machines (there's low inherent graphics requirements, but I guess the cookie counter updating continually might be an issue? But I am getting way way off topic and into semi-informed (at best) speculation for an aside at the end of a review on Steam here), I have no idea whether it actually will run for more than 10 seconds without something literally melting or whatever.

Now, to be clear, the performance improving massively would not change my review at all, because the issues I have are baked into the structure and nature of the game (pun not originally intended) but, hey, it's a point that might save someone from losing several hours of their life to this thing and it's worth bringing up just generally.

Clicker games have one job, this one failed.

You no longer get cookies unless the game is your active window on the computer. Yep, it's now an idle game you have to play to get anything out of. They've changed it from the browser version. You can "buy" an upgrade that gives you a fraction of your cookies while offline.

In short, this isn't an idle game. The game now expects you to actively sit and stare at cookie production for weeks on end and I for one have better things to do with my life. Alt-tab out for a second? Cookie production halts, best not cheat on cookie clicker with another game. Dumbest design decision of all time.

The grind to the second ascend is going to take forever and do barely anything.
-------------------------------------
It only took me a day to get 500 'legacy' and do my first awaken, I bought all the upgrades that seem worth it, plus some of the ones that give offline gains (which seem useless).

But now I'm looking at the upgrades down the line, and 1) they cost so many chips and 2) they barely help progress.

I just don't know if I can be bothered to continue, I feel like there should be more upgrades worth like 50-100 chips that provide decent bonuses.. But the next ones cost like 1000 chips and do barely anything, so the next time I awaken, for it to be worth it I'd need like 100k chips and that just seems insurmountable and is killing my buzz.

TLDR: Short grind for large reward was cool, but looks like I need a large grind for low rewards now :/

This is supposed to be an idler. Granted, I'm not terribly far in, but the early gameplay is fairly painful. No early offline progress means that even if you want to slowly progress to an offline play strat, you have to start with online. Numbers grow with some apparent meaning, but feels stagnant and hopeless early on, even for an Idler. Maybe an ascention or two will feel nicer, but the only things to differentiate this from other Idlers is cutesie (but still minimal) pictures and animation, and a cookie-themed marquee of useless cookie-world imaginings running along the top of the screen.

I wouldn't say it's heavy on CPU (best I can tell), but it's not worth its weight at the moment, prior to first ascention, 9 hours of play, much of it non-idle (a ton of power to be had non-idle, yet still not enough to feel impactful). That's a long while for basically no gameplay to speak of.

I get the feeling this older (I think?) title sparked a thing or two in the Idle genre on release (somehow I avoided this title), but others adapted and excelled over this one.

Unplayable. Play the free browser version instead. I could not even play for a total of 20 minutes, because I spent 10x as long with my PC frozen and eventually forced to hard-boot it because I couldn't even Ctrl+Alt+Del or Alt+F4 out. My PC met the game's specs, I set all the graphics on minimum, and it still locked my PC into a forced shutdown three times just because I hovered over a description or tried to close a menu.

I love the original browser version and have put hundreds of hours into it. I looked forward to finally having a dedicated paid version because of the hours of clicker-game addiction the devs have given me. This is not the version to buy.

If you like clicker/idle games, CC's browser version is a surprisingly game with years worth the content. Play that instead and throw the devs a few dollars on their Patreon or merch store.

An idle game that doesn't progress while closed means there's really not much going on with this game. Whenever you boot it up, you resume staring at the screen, waiting for cookies to accumulate so you can continue to make progress, building your cookie empire. The only moments of fun come when a golden cookie appears and you enter Frenzy mode for exactly 1 minute, 17 seconds. During this time, all production is increased by a magnitude of seven. This, in my experience, tends to happen every 10 minutes or so, which simply doesn't cut it for me. Try AdVenture Capitalist instead. Same concept, but actually functions like an idle game, and progresses when you're not there.
Just like a lot of clicker games out there. Nothing special. Would benefit from an idle option without having to have the game active
